merged_dataset_groups.topic_summary: The USPTO-2M dataset is primarily used for patent classification research, focusing on improving subclass-level accuracy through supervised learning. It is employed to fine-tune models like BERT, XLNet, and RoBERTa for multi-label classification, enhancing language understanding in the patent domain. The dataset supports the evaluation of hierarchical feature extraction, impact of patent sections, and word counts on classification performance. It also serves as a large-scale benchmark for training and evaluating models, including keyword extraction algorithms, and facilitates intellectual property retrieval tasks.

The CLEF-IP dataset is used for training and evaluating patent classification models, focusing on the performance and accuracy of NLP techniques in classifying patents from the United States Patent and Trademark Office. It supports linguistic experiments and enhances model robustness through supervised learning, particularly in English and German. The dataset provides large-scale, realistic patent data for developing and evaluating classification systems, enabling researchers to conduct comprehensive evaluations and improve classification accuracy.

The CLEF-IP 2011 dataset is primarily used for training and evaluating NLP models in the intellectual property domain, focusing on patent classification and information retrieval tasks. It supports research in extracting and encoding text from patent titles and abstracts, as well as abstractive summarization. Studies highlight its limitations in scope and coverage, making it useful for assessing the performance and limitations of patent classification systems.

The Patentsview dataset is utilized in research to extract and analyze patent data, particularly abstracts and claims, for training and evaluating machine learning models. It supports the development of classification models using deep learning techniques like CNN, Bi-LSTM, and BiLSTM-ATT-CRF. The dataset also aids in predicting patent maintenance periods and analyzing investor reactions through various machine learning approaches, including ANN and MLP.

The WIPO-alpha dataset is used to evaluate the performance of classifiers in patent categorization, specifically focusing on improving micro-F1 scores through ensemble methods and optimizing neural networks for higher accuracy. This dataset enables researchers to benchmark and refine machine learning models for more effective patent classification.

The OECD quality indicators dataset is used to evaluate the assessment of patent value using textual data. It provides quality metrics that enhance the evaluation process, focusing on the accuracy and reliability of patent valuation methods. This dataset enables researchers to refine and validate their models by offering standardized quality measures.

The corpus of 5 million patent documents is used to train fastText word embeddings, focusing on domain-specific language to improve patent classification accuracy using Bi-GRU models. It is also used to evaluate the precision of early works in patent classification, highlighting the impact of domain-specific word embeddings on model performance. This dataset enables researchers to enhance the accuracy and reliability of patent classification systems through advanced natural language processing techniques.

The Indonesian Patent Database is used to integrate region-specific innovations with global patent data, enhancing the capture of local innovation trends. It is also employed to improve the comprehensive coverage of patent information by combining global and local databases. This integration supports research focused on understanding and analyzing local innovation dynamics within a broader global context.

The CLEF-IP 2010 dataset is used to evaluate patent classification performance, focusing on micro-F1 and micro-precision metrics. It involves a subset of 532,264 English abstracts, enabling researchers to assess the accuracy and precision of classification models in the context of patent documents. This dataset facilitates the development and testing of natural language processing techniques tailored for patent classification tasks.

The 'gold standard data' dataset is used in patent classification NLP research to perform UMAP dimensional reduction on CPC class codes. This methodology helps visualize and illustrate potential causes and patterns in patent classification, enabling researchers to better understand the underlying structures and relationships within the data.

merged_dataset_groups.display_name: 1948 patent documents from United States Patent Classification (USPC) 360/324
name_variants: 1948 patent documents from United States Patent Classification (USPC) 360/324
merged_dataset_groups.topic_summary: The dataset of 1948 patent documents from USPC 360/324 is used to train a two-layered feed-forward neural network for patent classification. This approach focuses specifically on documents within the 360/324 classification, enabling researchers to develop and refine machine learning models for accurate patent categorization.

The M-patent dataset is used to train and evaluate neural network models for patent classification in natural language processing (NLP). Researchers apply early stopping techniques to prevent over-fitting during the training process, ensuring the models generalize well to new data. This dataset enables robust model development and evaluation, facilitating advancements in automated patent classification.

The WIPO datasets are specifically used for experimentation in patent classification, employing kernel classifier methods that account for the hierarchical structure of patents. These datasets enable researchers to develop and test classification models that accurately categorize patents within complex, multi-level classification systems.

The Cooperative Patent Classification dataset is used to organize patents into a hierarchical scheme, facilitating multi-label classification in the patent domain. It enhances the hierarchical organization of patents, supporting deep learning-based language understanding and improving the accuracy of classification tasks. This dataset enables researchers to develop and refine models that can effectively categorize patents, thereby enhancing the efficiency and precision of patent management and analysis.

The U.S. Patent Classification (USPC) dataset is used for technology class assignments in patent classification, providing a structured and hierarchical system to categorize patents by technological areas. It serves as a global standard, enabling detailed and harmonized classification compared to other systems like IPC. This dataset facilitates research in organizing and analyzing patent data, enhancing the accuracy and consistency of technology categorization.

The CPC’s IPC classification dataset is used to predict International Patent Classification (IPC) codes for patent documents. Research focuses on leveraging the hierarchical structure of the classification system using neural networks. This enables more accurate and automated classification of patents, enhancing the efficiency and precision of patent categorization processes.

The HUPD dataset is used to support patent classification tasks and to evaluate the prediction of patentability from claim text or abstracts. It is characterized as large-scale, well-structured, and multi-purpose, enabling researchers to develop and test models for classifying and assessing patent applications.

The USPTO patents dataset is used for part-of-speech tagging, focusing on linguistic analysis of patent classification. Researchers employ specific NLP methodologies to analyze the linguistic structure of patent texts, enabling detailed examination of terminology and classification systems within patents. This approach aids in understanding and improving the accuracy of patent classification through computational linguistics.

The English WIPO-alpha collection is used to evaluate the effectiveness of a patent classification model on a smaller scale, containing 75,250 patent documents. This dataset enables researchers to test and validate their models in a controlled environment, focusing on the accuracy and performance of classification algorithms.

The BigPatent 2 dataset is used for abstractive and coherent summarization of patent texts, processing over 1.3 million documents. It focuses on generating concise and accurate summaries, enabling researchers to efficiently extract key information from extensive patent literature. This dataset facilitates natural language processing (NLP) techniques aimed at improving the clarity and brevity of patent document summaries.

merged_dataset_groups.display_name: dataset containing 1.5 million patent claims annotated with patent class 1
name_variants: dataset containing 1.5 million patent claims annotated with patent class 1
merged_dataset_groups.topic_summary: The dataset containing 1.5 million patent claims annotated with patent class 1 is used to conduct experiments on patent classification, specifically focusing on the accuracy of classifying patent claims into specific classes. Researchers employ a deep NLP-based hybrid model to enhance classification precision, leveraging the large volume and annotated nature of the dataset to train and validate their models. This approach addresses the research question of improving the accuracy of patent claim classification.

merged_dataset_groups.display_name: a dataset created from patent information
name_variants: a dataset created from patent information
merged_dataset_groups.topic_summary: The dataset created from patent information is used to train Continuous Bag-of-Words (CBoW) and GloVe models for text classification, specifically focusing on enhancing word representation in patent documents. This approach aids in improving the accuracy of text classification tasks within the domain of patent documents, leveraging the unique vocabulary and technical language found in patents.

The USPTO bulk data is used to create a benchmark dataset for patent classification, specifically employing convolutional neural networks and word embedding techniques. This dataset enables researchers to develop and evaluate models for classifying patents, focusing on improving the accuracy and efficiency of automated classification systems.

The USPTO 2M 2006∼2014 dataset is primarily used for training and evaluating machine learning models, particularly BERT-based models, for patent classification. It focuses on sub-class labels and IPC codes, using titles, abstracts, and claim data from 2 million patents. The dataset enables researchers to compare and improve the performance of different models, demonstrating robustness and outperformance over state-of-the-art methods.

The CITATION-IP 2011 dataset is primarily used for abstractive summarization of patent documents, ensuring coherence and relevance in generated summaries. It is employed to train and evaluate NLP models for generating coherent abstracts from patent descriptions and to assess model performance in information retrieval and classification tasks. The dataset's large scale and focus on patent text make it suitable for comparing summarization techniques and evaluating NLP models in patent-related applications.

The USPTO Patent Examination Research Datasets are utilized to extract filing metadata such as acceptance decisions, filing dates, titles, and classification information. Researchers employ these datasets to conduct empirical analyses focused on patent examination processes. The datasets enable detailed investigations into the temporal and categorical aspects of patent filings, supporting research questions related to examination outcomes and procedural timelines.

PatentNet is primarily used for multi-label classification of patent documents, focusing on IPC classification, titles, and abstracts from USPTO patents (2006-2014). It is employed to train and evaluate deep learning models for enhancing language understanding in technical and legal contexts, with testing often conducted on 2015 data. The dataset supports pre-training language models and improving classification accuracy in patent document analysis.

The WikiBio dataset is used for patent classification NLP tasks, focusing on table-to-text generation and question-answering. It leverages the dataset's structured data and textual content to enhance these tasks, enabling researchers to develop and evaluate models that can effectively convert tabular data into coherent text and answer questions accurately.

The dataset 'C4' is mentioned in the citation context but lacks detailed descriptions of its usage, methodology, research questions, or specific characteristics. Therefore, there is insufficient evidence to provide a comprehensive synthesis of how this dataset is actually used in research.

The IFI CLAIMS Patent Services dataset is used to access and analyze bibliographic and full-text content from millions of US and international patent documents. It supports comprehensive patent research and analysis, enabling researchers to conduct detailed studies on patent trends, technological developments, and intellectual property landscapes. The dataset's extensive coverage of over 90 million documents from 17 countries facilitates robust and diverse research methodologies, enhancing the accuracy and depth of patent-related studies.

The '699,000 patents' dataset is used to train and test patent classification models, specifically focusing on IPC subclass level classification. Researchers employ a 70/30 training/testing data split to evaluate model performance. This dataset enables the development and validation of natural language processing techniques for patent classification, enhancing the accuracy and efficiency of categorizing patents into specific subclasses.

The EPO corpus is used to evaluate SVM-based models for patent classification, specifically focusing on the performance of combined handcrafted similarity and semantic features. This dataset enables researchers to assess the effectiveness of these feature combinations in classifying patents, contributing to the development of more accurate and robust classification systems.

The Patent classification dataset (He & Loh, 2007) is used to facilitate automatic patent classification by selecting the seven largest classes that address 20 of the 40 TRIZ Inventive Principles. This selection process aids in enhancing the accuracy and efficiency of patent classification systems, leveraging the dataset's structured class distribution and relevance to TRIZ principles.
